However, the presence of guest molecules in ice II has been a long-standing mystery. In this work, we report the synthesis and structure of a hydrate, neon hydrate, which is composed of water molecules and neon atoms. Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing the behavior of microscopic particles. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is a theory with a rich structure, and partly because it is a theory with a rich mathematical foundation. In this paper, we provide a mathematical foundation that is purely categorical and is based on the idea of Hilbert spaces. This foundation is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This work addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the myxozoan body plan is remarkably reduced in terms of genome size and gene content. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Abridged) more

The ability of the immune system to recognize and eliminate pathogens is a key component of the host defense system. In the case of viruses, the immune system can be either the first line of defense or the last line of defense, depending on the nature of the pathogen. In the latter case, the virus has evolved mechanisms to evade the host immune response. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by interfering with the nuclear import of these transcription factors. Our findings provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that may be used by SARS-CoV-2 to escape the antiviral response of the host. (Less)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline if the optimum growing temperature is exceeded. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes and consequences of their diversity. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. The survey also reveals substantial heterogeneity in the financial fragility of small businesses. Finally, we find that many small businesses are likely to apply for the CARES Act loans, but that they have concerns about the program’s bureaucratic complexity and eligibility requirements.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris by the ocean interior. This sink is likely to be a combination of processes that remove plastic debris from the surface, such as nano-fragmentation, and processes that remove plastic debris from the ocean interior, such as sinking. This sink may be of major importance to understand the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the origin of the universe. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the solar system formed in an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system formed in the protosolar nebula. The grains are the oldest presolar grains found in the solar system. They provide a unique window into the early solar system. The grains are now in the Australian National University Museum.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the global fishing fleet and its evolution over the last seven decades. It is the first to disaggregate the data into three sectors: artisanal (unpowered/powered) and industrial. It also provides a comprehensive analysis of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the marine ecosystem. The data are freely available for use in research and policy. The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also one of the most plastic. We show that the ability to reproduce is strongly correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is provided by domestication, allonursing, and the presence of other individuals in the group. We also show that the amount of energy available to the mother is strongly correlated with the size of the litter. This suggests that the ability to reproduce is a plastic response to the amount of energy available to the mother. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. The inflammatory protease caspase-1 has been implicated in the mechanisms that promote aggregation of α-syn in vitro and in neuronal cell models of α-syn toxicity. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of this drug to slow down the progression of MSA. This is the first study to show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in vivo. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is critical for the endothelium to control these functions. Here, we show that the communication network is highly efficient in transmitting signals between cells. The network is also highly dynamic, with cells being able to rapidly change their activities. The communication network is also highly connected, with many cells being connected to each other. This highly connected network is a small-world network, which is a network that is both efficient in transmitting signals and robust in maintaining its structure. The small-world network is a property that is not common in biological networks. The small-world network is a property that is likely to be important for the endothelium to control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to provide open access to data that can be used to monitor the pandemic and its impact. The API provides data on COVID-19 cases, deaths, and hospitalizations, as well as many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://covidcast.org.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for health and survival. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the microbiome is a relatively unexplored area of research. Here, we report the discovery of a diverse array of natural products produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These fungi are a previously uncharacterized source of natural products that could be exploited for the development of new therapeutics. This study provides a foundation for future research on the natural products of anaerobic fungi and the potential of these fungi to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. (Less)

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the mechanisms underlying this relationship are poorly understood. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We further show that this outcome is influenced by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. In particular, we demonstrate that high-anxious rats exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that microinfusion of mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduces social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious animals. Finally, we show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious rats. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to precisely control the mechanical response of a device is critical for its functionality. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we use a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular material distributions and exhibit organic shapes and motions. The responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work is expected to inspire the development of programmable materials and devices with complex and dynamic behaviors.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene family is the largest in the human genome and is responsible for the diversity of hemoglobin expression in humans. The hemoglobin genes are expressed in a developmental and tissue-specific manner. The hemoglobin genes are also expressed in a chronospecific manner, with fetal hemoglobin being expressed in the fetus and newborn and adult hemoglobin being expressed in adults. The mechanisms that control the expression of hemoglobin are not well understood. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is a potential regulator of the expression of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This study also provides evidence that the expression of fetal hemoglobin is controlled by a developmental and tissue-specific element. This element may be a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy. One of the main reasons for this failure is the emergence of drug resistance, which is often mediated by mutations in key signaling pathways. In this study, we show that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also show that this resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis, which is essential for the survival of cancer cells in the presence of oxidative stress. Finally, we demonstrate that the combination of ferroptosis induction and mTOR inhibition is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Less)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) protein. Our findings may help to explain the higher risk of heart failure associated with the use of these drugs and may lead to the development of new strategies to reduce this risk. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has stabilized, but declined in two ecoregions. These findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also suggest that the NWFP may not be sufficient to achieve the goals of the recently proposed revision of the plan.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational drug design for the discovery of new antibiotics. (Less)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results show that the proposed network architecture is a promising approach for solving many image-processing problems.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish are among the most diverse and best-known groups of freshwater fishes on Earth. They are endemic to the lake and have been used as a model system for studying speciation and adaptation. The lake is also one of the largest and deepest lakes in the world, and its hydroclimate has been shown to be sensitive to changes in the strength of the East African monsoon. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of lake-level variability from Lake Malawi. The record shows that the lake has been much lower in the past, and that the lake level has been highly variable. The record also shows that the lake has been much wetter in the past, and that the lake level has been highly variable. The hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime has a significant impact on sleep. The LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,300-y period of abrupt climate change that occurred 11,600 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB is consistent with terrestrial Os, and that the Os in the spherules is likely derived from the 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The Os isotopic composition of the spherules and their leachates is often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrial. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Abridged)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. We found that CTLA-4 deficiency induced a spectrum of autoimmunity, including lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity. This was not fatal, but was accompanied by a shift in the balance of Treg cells and Th cells.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and revealed that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory coincide with the first appearances of these genes in beetles. We propose that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. This study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation

The apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is also associated with differential risk of AD. APOE isoforms are synthesized by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. Here, we show that APOE isoforms regulate the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE isoforms regulate the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide insights into the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. This article is protected by copyright. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. The required degree of undercooling for the crystallization is too high to be achieved under core conditions. This contradiction is called the inner core nucleation paradox. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be the bcc phase than the hcp phase, which reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation. This two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core provides a solution to the paradox and opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results also provide a new perspective on the nucleation of other materials. (Simplified version available at the front of the article.)

The use of marijuana has increased dramatically in the United States, and the number of states that have legalized it has grown. The legalization of marijuana has led to a need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that increases extracellular dopamine [DA]), which is consistent with their increased negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a key factor in the development of addiction.

Language is the most complex behavior we know. How the human brain processes language is therefore one of the most important questions in neuroscience. We here show that the most powerful artificial neural networks also predict the brain’s responses to language in humans. This finding provides computational evidence that the brain’s language processing is fundamentally a process of predictive coding, in which the brain continually updates a model of the world based on evidence from the senses. The brain’s model is updated to better predict the sensory evidence, and the brain’s model of the world is updated to better match the evidence. This model-based processing is a hallmark of higher-level cognition and is thought to be disrupted in many neurological disorders. Our results suggest that predictive coding is a general mechanism of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL, but rather is a consequence of the difficulty of the optimization problem that DL solves. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can find a solution that is accurate to a given precision. This result is significant because it provides a classification of the conditions under which a given problem can be solved by an algorithm. We also introduce a new class of neural networks that we prove are stable and numerically verify to be fast and accurate. This work is a step toward the goal of making scientific computing more accessible to deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 y. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of how to study human response to exponential growth. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its etiology has been the subject of much speculation. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of the well-studied Mycobacterium leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that the ancient separation of the two species has not prevented them from causing similar diseases. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the leprosy pathogens and their pathogenic mechanisms. (Summary by David Barile)

The emergence of thermodynamics from quantum dynamics is a central problem in quantum mechanics. The entanglement dynamics is the most direct way to study this issue, as it is the only way to access the system’s internal structure. However, the entanglement dynamics is a highly nonlinear process, which makes it difficult to analyze. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. Our results are exact and valid in the limit of large system size. They are in excellent agreement with numerical simulations, and they provide a general framework for the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The vaccine is being tested in humans, but the results are not yet available. In the meantime, it is important to develop alternative vaccines that can be used in the event of a vaccine failure. Here, we describe a vaccine that is based on the same virus but is much safer and more effective. The vaccine is based on recoding the viral genome to remove the risk of replication in the absence of the host temperature. The recoded virus is much safer and more effective than the wild-type virus. The recoded virus is also much easier to manufacture on a large scale. This makes the recoded virus a promising candidate for use in a mass vaccination program. The recoded virus is currently being tested in humans. The results of this trial will be available soon. If the results are positive, the recoded virus will be a promising candidate for use in a mass vaccination program. If the results are negative, the recoded virus will still be a promising candidate for use in a mass vaccination program.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the Black Death, which caused the pandemic, is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague and its vectors. It also has implications for the control of plague today.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known phenomenon in biology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. This study is the first to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes, the group that includes birds and mammals. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. The results also suggest that the evolution of brain neuronal density may be a key factor in the rise of complex cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. (Mol Cancer Ther; 10(1): 159–168, 2011)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a key process in many cellular processes, including cell motility and cytokinesis. However, the mechanism by which ADF severes filaments is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF-induced curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Surprisingly, we also find that ADF-induced filament torque dramatically enhances severing. A simple model, which faithfully reproduces our experimental observations, suggests that the ADF-induced filament torque increases the severing rate constant by 100-fold. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is a general principle in severing by ADF and other ADF-like proteins. Our findings have implications for our understanding of severing in cells and for the design of new drugs that target severing.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food-seeking behavior. The results also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. This may help explain why some people are more susceptible to the obesogenic effects of fructose. The findings may also help explain why some people are more susceptible to the obesogenic effects of sugar-sweetened beverages. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique. We found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, suggesting that Madagascar was settled in a few centuries. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a new perspective on the settlement history of the Indian Ocean islands. (Less)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that people’s own emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media, and for our understanding of the influence of others on our emotions.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on mRNA function has only recently been appreciated. The most common modification in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which is present in 10–20% of nucleotides. We show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the recruitment of the elongation factor EF-Tu and the initiation of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a modest impact on translation. The presence of Ψ in mRNAs is widespread, and our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a modest impact on translation. This may have important implications for the function of mRNAs in cells. (Less)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and more favorable lifestyle behaviors. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounders and predictors, and they are maintained over time. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body size is a defining feature of aquatic life, but the mechanisms driving this pattern remain unclear. We use a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that aquatic life is driving the evolution of larger body size in mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results suggest that the aquatic environment is driving and confining the evolution of larger body size in mammals. This study provides a quantitative test of the role of the aquatic environment in driving the evolution of body size in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and most rhinovirus isolates replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. The mechanism of temperature-dependent growth is not well understood. We show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more robust antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at nasal cavity temperature. This difference in the magnitude of the antiviral defense response at different temperatures is critical for the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus. These findings have implications for understanding the temperature-dependent growth of other viruses. (Summary by David Janssen)

The type IV pili (T4P) of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including biofilm formation and pathogenicity. In this study, we show that the T4P of P. aeruginosa are also involved in a new sensing mechanism. The T4P of P. aeruginosa are involved in the sensing of surfaces, which is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system. This system is similar to the chemotaxis system, but instead of sensing the environment, it senses the surface. This sensing mechanism is important for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa, as it allows the bacterium to sense the surface of the host, and to respond accordingly.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this has led to increasing contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is the first of its kind. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is important for the global community because it provides a comprehensive overview of the pesticide situation and the risks it poses to the environment and human health. It is also important for the scientific community because it provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and the risks it poses to the environment and human health. This study is expected to be of interest to a wide range of readers, including scientists, policy makers, and the general public.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and society. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animals is a major concern, as it could lead to the emergence of new variants that are more transmissible or virulent. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter, when human cases are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a “One Health” approach is needed to better understand the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world since the 1970s. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the toxic effects of Aβ are not limited to the formation of plaques, but also occur in the brain parenchyma, where Aβ is released in soluble and oligomeric forms. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing a variety of inflammatory factors in response to Aβ, even in the absence of plaques. This neuron-derived inflammatory response correlates with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, and is found in the human brain at the earliest stages of the disease. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary source of the neuroinflammation that is believed to be a key component of the AD pathogenesis. This study provides insight into the earliest events in AD, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how the folding of a large protein is accomplished. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural detail. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to have distinct native-like intermediates in its folding pathway. We find that the intermediates are not the end of the folding pathway but are instead the beginning of the pathway. This finding suggests that the intermediates are important steps in the folding process. The results are consistent with the idea that the folding of a large protein is accomplished by a series of distinct steps. This is an important step in understanding the folding of large proteins. (Abridged)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism of stress signaling in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also activated by stress, and that this enzyme has the ability to recognize and decape Np4-capped RNAs. The unusual manner in which this enzyme recognizes capped 5′ termini positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for cleavage, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which the cellular concentration of alarmones can be regulated in response to stress. (Less)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, an amino acid that is converted to arginine in the body, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic strategy in other diseases in which arginine is overproduced. (Citrulline is a potential therapeutic strategy in other diseases in which arginine is overproduced.) (Less)

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. We provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, including plants, animals, bacteria, and archaea. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are essential for understanding the structure and functioning of the planet.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, despite external perturbations. SOC is observed in nature, such as earthquakes, sandpiles, and fire fronts. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, and is a continuous version of the Ising model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control due to its high symmetry. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, or metallized, by applying strain. We also show that the electronic properties of diamond can be tuned continuously by strain. This work provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, which will be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of plant-derived fungicides. However, the mode of action of these peptides is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides insights into the mode of action of this class of peptides and opens up a new avenue for the development of plant-derived fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Less)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for blood clotting, but its function is regulated by the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the function of VWF in the blood.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health and disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, highlight the scientific potential of the dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The findings of this study will have a significant impact on our understanding of ACI. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The earliest life on Earth is thought to have originated in the oceans, and the evolution of life is thought to be dependent on the temperature of the surface environment. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been inferred from isotopic data, but this has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic composition of the oceans, the possibility of isotopic resetting, and the depositional environment. We have used the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to determine the temperature of the surface environment of ancient organisms, and our results are consistent with the surface temperature decreasing over geological time. This finding is consistent with the evolution of life being dependent on the temperature of the surface environment. This study demonstrates the value of integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data to provide new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in excitable cells and are important for the transmission of nerve impulses and the contraction of muscles. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the control of their functions. The K+ channel, BK, is a major regulator of vascular tone and plays a key role in the regulation of cardiac rhythm. The BK channel is unique in that it has no classic intracellular activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Less)

The malaria parasite must invade the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle and cause disease. The parasite uses a number of mechanisms to facilitate invasion, including the binding of its adhesin to the host RBC glycophorin A. Here, we show that this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first demonstration that the parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This finding has implications for our understanding of the invasion process and may provide a target for the development of new antimalarial therapies.

We also show that the electronic properties of diamond can be tuned continuously by strain. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus disease. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of syntactic structure is not sequential, but rather unfolds in a hierarchical manner, with each word contributing to the formation of a phrase. This hierarchical structure is consistent with the way humans construct sentences in their heads, and it provides a neural basis for the linguistic theory of merge operations. Our results suggest that the brain may be able to process the complexity of natural language more efficiently than previously thought.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in many developmental processes. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of redundant genes and may help in the design of more effective gene therapy strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), as well as by dopamine neurons in the LH. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the VTA or SNr, and that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH GABA neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their bacteria would be a major advance in agriculture. We have developed a system for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the plant can sense the presence of its bacterial symbiont and activate the nitrogen-fixing process only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a transkingdom signal. The use of rhizopine as a transkingdom signal is a promising strategy for the engineering of plant–microbe interactions.

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. The Global Forest Watch (GFW) network provides a valuable tool for monitoring deforestation, but it is not always clear whether alerts are generated in time to prevent deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses GFW alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests and reduce deforestation. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the program may have unintended consequences. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which is better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously estimated, and that the climate benefits are much larger than previously estimated. We also show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are strongly coupled to the climate benefits, and that the climate benefits are strongly coupled to the reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. Our results suggest that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the availability of a safe and efficacious vaccine at a low cost is critical. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production, which could yield billions of doses annually. This vaccine candidate is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that is more easily bound by antibodies and has enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. The engineered RBD is also more resistant to variants of concern. This vaccine candidate could be a critical component of a global vaccine supply. (Less)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system and are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the ALKALs. We further show that the ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived cells. Our results provide evidence that the ALKALs are ligands for the ALK/LTK family of receptors and that this receptor complex is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This study provides insight into the role of ALK/LTK receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex process that is still not fully understood. The study of ancient plague genomes has provided new insights into the origins of plague, but the number of genomes recovered is still too small to explore the diversity of the pathogen during its formative years. Here, we present 17 plague genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this period. We find that the plague lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic that devastated Europe and Asia in the 14th century CE was already present in Eurasia at this time. This study provides new insights into the early history of plague and its relationship with its vector, the flea. (Less)

The endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—is associated with men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. This study provides evidence that HM is a powerful predictor of men’s and women’s support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The findings are consistent with the idea that HM is a cultural ideology that legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The agricultural use of grasslands has been shown to be a major contributor to the loss of soil organic carbon (SOC) from agricultural soils. However, the extent to which this loss can be reversed by alternative agricultural practices is not well understood. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for disease prevention and control. The database can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies to mitigate their spillover and spread.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators is nectar, which is produced by specialized glands in the flower. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the quality of the reward. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also show that this alkaloid is attractive to the most likely pollinators of this plant, the gecko lizards. This work demonstrates that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work also provides evidence that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This is important because it suggests that the search for the “magic molecule” that underlies nectar color may be futile. Instead, the search for the “magic molecules” that underlie the evolution of vertebrate pollination may be more fruitful.

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Roman Empire and the early Middle Ages is poorly understood. This is due to the lack of population-level genome data from this period. Here we present a genome-wide dataset from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 750 CE. The analysis of this dataset indicates that the genetic ancestry of men from this period is similar to that of modern northern and central Europeans. However, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is also reflected in the functional variants that we identified, which indicate that women differed in visible characteristics. Our results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells. These findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing strategies to prevent and control future outbreaks of zoonotic coronaviruses. This article is

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens is a major public health concern. The ability to rapidly identify these pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) on sera from febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including dengue virus, Plasmodium knowlesi, and leptospirosis. Our findings highlight the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to rapidly deploy public health response. (Simplified version available at adis.asm.org)

The human genome is replicated in the nucleus by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) holoenzyme, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results also suggest that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more similar to the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme than previously thought. This study provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the human pol δ holoenzyme. It also provides a foundation for future studies of the structure and function of the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but the process is inefficient and requires the use of proteins. Here, we report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that dramatically improves the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, allowing it to synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.
