The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are similar, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results provide a new therapeutic strategy for severe and critical COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper levels is critical for their survival in the environment and in the human body. Here we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a source of natural products that regulate copper homeostasis and that these products may be important in fungal interactions with the human body. Frost is a major abiotic stress that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of leaf-out dates and leaf-freezing resistance of woody plants to infer trees’ adaptations for minimizing frost damage to their leaves and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is not well understood. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model, indicating that they require the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells to induce disease. This transition required the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Th17 cells could also provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the functional significance of these mechanisms may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks is a complex community of bacteria that is critical for the survival of the tick. We now show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed in the gut and that it alters the composition of the gut microbiota. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector and may have implications for vector control. (Less)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in avian evolution, as it is the last common ancestor of the tail and the origin of the pygostyle, a compound bone at the end of the tail. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia are critical for understanding the origin of the pygostyle, but the currently limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is formed when iron is released from hemoglobin. These proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins (BBS), are most similar to human antiproteases, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates. (Less)

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is critical for their ability to metastasize and survive in the tumor microenvironment. We show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of pluripotency factor NANOG and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the induction of BCSCs by hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment may contribute to the maintenance of BCSCs and the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize. This may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Summary by John Simon)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Ma, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction, and the system remained volatile for ∼500 ka. The extinction was followed by a period of ecosystem reorganization, which may have contributed to the recovery of the biota. The age model presented here will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This work will also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium (IE) is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the viral spike protein, and it has been suggested to be associated with increased infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutant spike is in a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. They also provide a basis for the development of vaccines and therapeutics that target the mutant spike. (Less)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the well-known result for finite games. It also has applications to the study of the behavior of markets with many traders.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of the periodic table. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of fundamental importance for chemistry and for the periodic table. They also provide a new perspective on the origin of the periodic table.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and suppression can have a large influence on the future trajectory of fire activity, and that this can have a significant impact on the rate of warming. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems means that the potential benefits of reduced ignitions and suppression are not guaranteed. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and the carbon cycle. This is critical for understanding the potential impacts of climate change on the global carbon cycle and the role of terrestrial ecosystems in the climate system.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thereby maintained at a constant level. The glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is active, and the catabolism of the glycan is required for the symbiont to maintain its luminescence. This is the first example of a nutrient being provided to a symbiont in a diel rhythm, and it suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more common phenomenon than previously thought.

The study of topics in text is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on a new type of embedding, which we call discourse atom embeddings. Discourse atoms are latent topics that can be interpreted as word distributions. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to many domains, including the analysis of social media, news, and literature. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images and videos. Our method can be used to identify latent patterns in text data and to represent documents as topic sequences.

The Black Death, which occurred in Europe in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease was caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which is transmitted by fleas. The origin of this plague is still debated, but the most widely accepted hypothesis is that the bacterium was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the bacterium for centuries before the disease arrived in Europe. This suggests that the bacterium was introduced into Europe repeatedly, rather than once, and that the disease was not established in Europe until the climate conditions were favorable for its spread.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a major prey item for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of a wasting disease. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus in asteroids. The virus is likely to be a major factor in the decline of this important marine ecosystem component.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. In this study, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the antibody can also suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that the antibody can be used as a therapeutic agent for the treatment of other types of cancer. (Less)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique. We found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was the result of multiple independent colonization events. Finally, we found that the genomic diversity of Madagascar is already structured, suggesting that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a unique view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD). We found that overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that the RNA also base pairs with the promoter of two other genes, cadA and galE. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that encodes a protein and base pairs with a promoter.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show how to statistically model the underlying crop models, and demonstrate how to use the resulting models to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, and can be extended to other applications in agriculture and beyond.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where information is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that the firing rates of single neurons are dependent on the context of the stimulus and that these changes in excitability can be used to store information. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The plastid genome is the only genome that is not part of the core genome of the host. It is therefore a unique window into the evolution of the host’s genome. The evolution of the plastid genome is shaped by the host’s environment, and the plastid genome is a key player in the host’s adaptation to its environment. We show that the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is linked to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the functional complexity of the plastid genome. The evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome, and the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are linked to the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security. The contribution of anthropogenic climate change to this prolonged rainfall deficit has been estimated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear SSA rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The first test explosion of a nuclear weapon, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” The discovery of this material, which is now known as “red trinitite,” has led to the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. This discovery demonstrates that quasicrystals can be formed by extreme pressure–temperature conditions, and that the discovery of quasicrystals is not a phenomenon of modern science.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic isoprenoid unit, is a key step in this process. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Abridged)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the regulation of neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in microglia/macrophages, astrocytes, or T cells, and we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Further, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages induces a proinflammatory environment, which subsequently activates astrocytes to exacerbate neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades because of the combined effects of human-caused warming and natural variability. Our results suggest that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions will continue to increase in the future, which will likely lead to more severe droughts in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. The causal pathways that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility are not well understood. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may help to identify the causal pathways that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the store-operated Ca2+ release-activated Ca2+ (SO) channel protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the SO channel, and show that they cause bleeding diathesis and a congenital myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SO channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SO channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Less)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets. (Less)

The bat is the only mammal that has been shown to be a reservoir of multiple zoonotic viruses, including the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 1. However, the mechanisms that facilitate virus spillover from bats to humans are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein is a potent immunosuppressant that facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential explanation for the origin of the bat as a reservoir of zoonotic viruses. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer growth in mice, and that the cancer cells are dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for growth. We also show that the cancer cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT for glycine import, and that this deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These studies provide a foundation for the development of a therapeutic strategy for colon cancer and other cancers that depend upon SHMT enzymatic activity. They also provide a metabolic target for the treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. (Less)

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in the brains of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that the disease is caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, but not in other tissues. We show that the average supersaturation of these proteins is greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these proteins in motor neurons, but not when the average supersaturation is calculated from other human tissues. These results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be a period of great diversity in the evolution of plants. The Cretaceous is also known for the appearance of the first flowering plants, which are now the dominant plants on land. The earliest flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the Cretaceous is known for the appearance of the first aquatic flowering plants. The study of the aquatic flowering plant Montsechia, described here, raises questions about the origin of this group and the early evolution of flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, including fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the acceleration reported by the IPCC AR5. This result provides a more precise estimate of the sea level acceleration and its climate forcing. It also provides a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is important for understanding the impacts of sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions, provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity. This detailed picture of the active site, including the location and orientation of crystallographic waters, is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The study of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate is critical to understanding the mechanism of the reaction, and the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to this species provides a powerful tool for mechanistic enzymology. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity in enzyme catalysis. (Abridged)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that has a high mortality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the only treatment options are supportive care. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment initiated 12 h postinoculation provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of MERS. (Less)

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most complex and diverse interactions in nature. The molecular mechanisms that regulate these associations are poorly understood, in part because the vast majority of these interactions are not amenable to genetic manipulation. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the host animal can regulate the activities of the symbiont and the health of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the animal is active and the symbiont is producing light. This glycan-regulated rhythmicity is a mechanism for the animal to control the activities of the symbiont, and may be a general mechanism for the control of symbiosis.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate impact on students of color and students with disabilities. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and well-being. The study also shows that suspension rates can be reduced without increasing the number of students suspended. This is an important step toward reducing the disproportionate impact of suspension on students of color and students with disabilities. The study also has implications for the use of data on suspensions in school accountability systems.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the stalling profiles are correlated with the fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) proteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. The cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the world’s population are a key driver of this problem, and there is a need to develop effective strategies for changing these choices. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces. The approach is simple to implement, requires no new technology, and has low cost and minimal disruption to the catering operation. The results suggest that this approach could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. Further research is needed to understand the impact of this approach in different settings and to explore the potential for scaling up. This work has the potential to make a significant contribution to the global sustainability agenda.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We apply quantitative proteomics to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with whole cell glycoproteomics enabled by a recently developed technique called activated ion electron transfer dissociation. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to the general scientific community, as well as to the cancer research community.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented without compromising the integrity of the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the virus and its interactions with the host. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a foundation for understanding the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxic stress induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxic stress. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. This is the idea of “selective inference”: We should only accept as “true” the conclusions that we have earned by searching for the strongest evidence. In the era of big data, however, it is becoming increasingly difficult to find the strongest evidence. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference that allow us to make more judicious use of the data that we have.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells has been challenging. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells. This finding provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, the generation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. These findings may lead to the development of a new strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a variety of physiological processes. In the last few years, two new RTKs have been identified, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk), which are involved in the development of several types of cancer. Here, we show that these two RTKs are also involved in the development of zebrafish eyes and pigmentation. We also show that the ligands of these two RTKs are essential for the development of these organs. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands of these two RTKs and their downstream signaling molecules. This study also provides a model system for studying the physiological role of RTKs and their ligands. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Although insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for T2D, the role of STING in these two molecular bases is unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired insulin secretion in β-cells, leading to glucose intolerance. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a potential source of genetic diversity. However, the influenza A virus genome is packaged into virions in a selective manner, in which only one copy of each viral RNA is packaged into each virion. The molecular details of this selective packaging mechanism are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our experiments suggest that the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome is based on a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This network might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Understanding the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism might provide a basis for the development of antiviral strategies. (Less)

The atheroprone flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential formation of atherosclerotic lesions are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the formation of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the atheroprone flow environment and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires. We show that human-started wildfires have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that the human-started fire season is three times longer than the lightning-caused fire season. Actions to reduce the extent of human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of anthropogenic and natural stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is currently being driven by global warming. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral Stylophora pistillata to heat stress are driven by altered nutrient cycling. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, ultimately leading to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the microbiome can alter the activity of tumors. We also show that the activity of JNK signaling is critical for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and for maintaining homeostasis between the host and the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of the microbiome in cancer progression. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse and die from the disease. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells and is up-regulated following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Finally, we show that ROR1 expression is required for the ability of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Less)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is controversial, with some studies suggesting that deglaciation began as early as ∼19.5 ka, while others argue that deglaciation only began after a period of ∼100 y with little or no change in climate. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is precisely coincident with the start of massive volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a period of unusually warm climate conditions. This finding provides strong evidence that the start of deglaciation was triggered by a volcanic eruption, and it suggests that the start of deglaciation may have been triggered by a volcanic eruption rather than by a change in the position of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This finding has implications for our understanding of the timing and causes of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in conservation and policy. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security and biodiversity conservation. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. This highlights the need to protect the world’s rivers from the multiple threats they face, including overfishing. Our data can be used to inform the design of policies to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries and their contribution to food security. This will be critical for the future of this important ecosystem service.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by disrupting neuronal activity. We also identify a form of regeneration in the mammalian CNS that is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite and is enhanced by disrupting neuronal activity. These connections suggest that the mechanisms that control regeneration in the mammalian CNS may be conserved in the C. elegans nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to precisely locate the locations of recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination occurs at a high rate in the promoter regions of genes, but at a low rate in the coding regions of genes. We also find that the rate of recombination varies greatly across the genome, with some regions of the genome showing no evidence of recombination. This study provides a detailed view of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant, and may provide insights into the evolution of recombination in other organisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level–dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a set of topographies, or networks, that are functionally related. Here, we used metabolic PET to identify and validate the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects, and to demonstrate that this network is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also demonstrated that the dominant network is reduced in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this reduction is present at diagnosis. These results provide a direct link between the functional and metabolic organization of the brain. They have implications for the understanding of the neurobiology of human brain function.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The existence of 5′ cap-like structures on RNAs other than tRNA and rRNA has been suggested, but their existence has not been proven. We show that 5′ NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This is the first example of a 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes. The existence of 5′ NAD+ RNA on subsets of mRNAs suggests that it may have a role in mRNA regulation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me alterations at certain loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). In vitro, high glucose induced similar persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in cultured blood monocytes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms of metabolic memory and to identify biomarkers for its prediction and/or assessment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides evidence that gut dysfunction is associated with relapse.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is largely unknown, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. (Less)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of global change. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of global change on the thermal tolerance of species, and suggest that biodiversity loss may be exacerbated by the additional impacts of environmental warming. This work is important for understanding the impacts of global change on the functioning of ecosystems, and for developing strategies to mitigate these impacts.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is divided into superficial and deep layers, and the superficial layers are subdivided into three sublayers. The superficial layers are thought to be important for the formation of grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation. However, the anatomical and functional organization of the superficial layers is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically organized, and that the organization of grid cells is different from that of other neurons in the superficial layers. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the superficial layers of MEC. They will be useful for understanding the function of the MEC. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by many genes and environmental factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host plant, but not for flowering of the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of how flowering is regulated in plants.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides insights into the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system and may have implications for understanding the function of this system in health and disease.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This may be why we click with some people and not with others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, called sinoatrial cells (SACSs), which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also the site of the natural pacemaker potential, which is the driving force for the heart rate. The heart rate is regulated by the autonomic nervous system, and the SAN is also sensitive to the sympathetic nervous system. In this study, we found that the store-operated Ca2+ entry channel STIM1 is expressed in the SAN, and its deletion in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in SAN cells and led to a reduction in heart rate. These results suggest that STIM1 is a regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells. This study also provides a mechanism for the regulation of heart rate by the autonomic nervous system. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to enhance plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may have important implications for the use of Si in crop protection. (Abbrev. running title: Silicon and jasmonate interact in rice defense against insect herbivores) (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme that is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where information is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that the firing rates of single neurons are dependent on the context of the stimulus and that these changes in excitability can be used to store information. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of functional biomolecules to plants is challenging due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are critical design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and other ecological and economic impacts. The nutrient sources fueling these blooms are often unknown, however, because of the difficulty of measuring nutrient inputs from large water bodies. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our findings reveal that small watersheds are important sources of nutrients to the lake, and that the nutrient loads from small watersheds are high for their size. This suggests that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our findings have implications for the management of other large water bodies worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is made available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a rare combination of forces. We show that this behavior is a consequence of the network’s topology, and we discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against the NMDA receptor can change the intrinsic properties of the cortical microcircuit, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that the same changes in microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibody. They also suggest that the same changes in microcircuitry may be tolerated in the absence of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may explain why the clinical course of the disease is unpredictable in some patients. Finally, our findings may help to identify patients who are likely to benefit from immunotherapy. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and the causes of this warming are being debated. One of the most important factors that determines the magnitude of warming is the amount of organic matter that is buried in sediments. Here, we show that a major global warming event occurred during a glacial period, and we demonstrate that the organic matter burial was enhanced by the injection of organic matter into the deep ocean. This organic matter burial likely contributed to the global warming.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil, a commodity responsible for substantial tropical deforestation. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia by 33%. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a panacea for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce tropical deforestation.
